bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, October 21, 1921

div1.p: Hanson sends Carter a Spanish translation of a lecture. Some inspectors are returning to the Canal Zone. He hopes to bring his family to Peru. There has been an outbreak of bubonic plague. He offers his opinions on the Peruvian government.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, October 21, 1921
div1.opener:
DIRECCION DE LA CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EN LOS
DEPARTAMENTOS DEL NORTE
----
OFICINA CENTRAL
-----
Hanson
Oct 21/21
H. R. C
Chiclayo, Peru.
October 21,1921.
Dr. Henry R. Carter, Asst Surgeon General,
United States Public Health Service,
Washington, D.C.
My Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I am sending you the spanish translation of the talk which
I gave before the Medical Society of the Canal Zone. I hope you will critizese
what you think is incorrect in the thing. It was purely an impromptu talk, but they
had a stenographer there to take it and sent me a copy of the same. I gave the
English copy to my interpretor and asked him if he thought it was worht trans-
lating, with the result that you have the enclosed. I shall send Dr. White a copy
also, and if you think it is worth it you can forward it to the I.H.B. I like the
spanish version better than I do the English, besides I only have one English copy
and no time to make any more.

Corrigan and Pickett have left for the Canal Zone, and I am now depending
on Dunn and Seeley. Seeley thought he was going to have to leave, as his wife rather
insisted on his coming back or bringing the family down here. I think he should stay
to the finish, it is going to be very important to have enough reliable men to de-
pend on for the finish, and I have made the arrangement which you will note in the
copy of this letter. Seeley has done very good work and an enormous amount of it.

Under the circumstances Corrigan and Pickett were worth what they got in
this years campaign. They had the experience of last year, both in knowing the
people and the conditions, and besides they worked like very few men ever have
worked except in time an engagement in actual warfare. The practically had no rest
on any day from the time they landed until the sailed for the statesCanal. Their effect
on the native inspectors was good, kept them on the qui vive for fear they were
going to be caught with their districts in bad shape.

If I can get a decent place for the folks I think I will bring my family
to Trujillo, as the warm weather seems to be too much for Mrs. Hanson in Panama and

CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EN LOS
DEPARTAMENTOS DEL NORTE
----
OFICINA CENTRAL
-----
" 2. H.R.C., October 21, 1921
besides I want her and the kiddies where I can see them occasionally. If they dont
come down I would go up to be with them for Christmas, but I believe it is better
for them to come down here. This climate is about the best one can get, and they
have had a pretty long pull with the heat. They only bad feature is the bubonic
plague which is serious. Here in Chiclayo we have had plague in one of the best
families, and the Salubridad seem to be doing nothing about it as usual. They do
not even have good vaccine or serum. I wonder if you could get me some relaible
serum and vaccine sent down from New York, or somewhere, probably the U.S.P.H.S.
has some it could send.

Wrightson is getting up a reorganization sheet for the Health Depat
ment which in my opinion is entirely impractical, and does not suit the condit-
ions of the country at the present time. However that is his funeral, not mine.

Up to the present we have used neary four hundred thousand fish in the
campaign, and with good results. The use of fish is the ticket, and they only
one where the conditions lend them selves freely to it. If I ever can get time
to get up a proper general report on this thing, I shall give details and re-
sults on this method of campaigning.

I hope you have received the information which I sent up for you
on my return from Panama.
I havent time to write more today,
div1.closer: With best wishes, Very sincerely your friend, Henry Hanson.
